elements.content: Three novel pendant acetate complexes, [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−M+, [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl2(py)], and [Ir­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−M+ (bdmpza = bis­(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl) acetate, M+ = Li+, Na+), were synthesized. Abstraction of halide from these complexes with silver salts yielded species capable of C–H activation of arenes. The catalytic H/D exchange reaction between benzene and trifluoroacetic acid-d was optimized, and these conditions were used to evaluate H/D exchange in other arenes. Branched alkyl substituents in alkyl aromatics showed an affinity toward deuterium exchange in the β-alkyl position only. DFT calculations were performed to determine the mechanism of H/D exchange.

elements.content: There have been many studies and reviews on C–H activation/functionalization over the past 30 years. Almost all of these reference the Shilov system for alkane C–H bond activation/functionalization, which has been widely studied and remains one of the most effective catalytic systems for hydrocarbons. Several research groups, particularly those of Zamashchikov and Bercaw, have studied the mechanism of the Shilov system extensively, finding that the C–H activation is the rate-determining step.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

There have been many studies and reviews on C-H activation/functionalization over the past 30 years. Almost all of these reference the Shilov system for alkane C-H bond activation/functionalization, which has been widely studied and remains one of the most effective catalytic systems for hydrocarbons. Several research groups, particularly those of Zamashchikov and Bercaw, have studied the mechanism of the Shilov system extensively, finding that the C-H activation is the rate-determining step.

elements.content: Numerous studies have sought to improve this system through variation of the ancillary ligands at PtII. For example, Periana found that use of a bipyrimidine ligand stabilized the system toward precipitation of Pt0. Recently, Vedernikov reported the use of the fac-chelating ligand di­(2-pyridyl)­methanesulfonate (dpms) to stabilize PtIV using oxygen coordination in PtII/PtIV C–H activation reactions. The two-electron oxidation is facilitated by coordination of the sulfonate tail of the scorpionato ligand (Scheme ); however, while methanol is produced, the system has only been found to work stoichiometrically to date. fac-chelating ligands may be the key to improving the Shilov system, but other metals should also be considered to improve the efficiency of the system.

elements.content: Periana has reported using iridium with a wide variety of ancillary ligands to achieve C–H bond activation/functionalization, and more recently he reported the use of rhodium with an O-donor ligand and a tetradentate diamine-bis­(phenolate). Both complexes showed the ability to activate arene C–H bonds, with the Rh/O-donor ligand system obtaining 114 turnovers in 11.5 h. Fagnou has shown the mechanism of palladium acetate direct arylation, through theoretical calculations and experimental data, to undergo C–H activation by a concerted metalation–deprotonation (CMD) mechanism, in which an acetate is intricately involved in the C–H activation. Herein we report new rhodium and iridium complexes with the fac-chelating ligand bis­(3,5 dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)­acetate (bdmpza) that are active in sp2 and sp3 C–H bond activation.

Herein we report new rhodium and iridium complexes with the fac-chelating ligand bis(3,5 dimethylpyrazol-1-yl)acetate (bdmpza) that are active in sp2 and sp3 C-H bond activation.

elements.content: Lithium bis­(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl) acetate (Li-bdmpza) was prepared according to literature methods. Initial reactions of Li-bdmpza with metal salts were conducted by gently heating RhCl3·nH2O and Li-bdmpza in ethanol, permitting isolation of the new rhodium­(III) complex [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−Li+ (Li-1). The 1H NMR spectrum shows the anticipated ligand resonances and an additional broad peak at δ 10.8. Upon repeated synthesis of Li-1 it was found that the amplitude of this high-field peak was variable. Fortunately, X-ray-quality crystals could be grown by evaporation of THF and a structure was obtained (Figure ). The bdmpza ligand can be seen to be κ3 to the rhodium, and the lithium cation is located 1.882(5) Å from the noncoordinated carbonyl oxygen. A water molecule is bound to the lithium, and there are interactions with two chloride ligands of a neighboring molecule of Li-1 (CN = 4). This hydrated ion pair can be observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of these same crystals with the same chemical shift of δ 10.8. Removal of the water proved difficult even under vacuum. The resonance at δ 10.8 could be reduced, but not completely removed, suggesting that the ion pair remains in contact in solution. An elemental analysis was successfully obtained following cation exchange with tetraethylammonium chloride in ethanol, giving a product which no longer contained water, Et 4 N-1. X-ray analysis of this material showed it to be water-free.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of bdmpza Complexes

Lithium bis(3,5-dimethylpyrazol-1-yl) acetate (Li-bdmpza) was prepared according to literature methods. Initial reactions of Li-bdmpza with metal salts were conducted by gently heating RhCl3⋅nH2O and Li-bdmpza in ethanol, permitting isolation of the new rhodium(III) complex [Rh(bdmpza)Cl3]-Li+ (Li-1). The 1H NMR spectrum shows the anticipated ligand resonances and an additional broad peak at δ 10.8. Upon repeated synthesis of Li-1 it was found that the amplitude of this high-field peak was variable. Fortunately, X-ray-quality crystals could be grown by evaporation of THF and a structure was obtained (Figure ). The bdmpza ligand can be seen to be κ3 to the rhodium, and the lithium cation is located 1.882(5) Å from the noncoordinated carbonyl oxygen. A water molecule is bound to the lithium, and there are interactions with two chloride ligands of a neighboring molecule of Li-1 (CN = 4). This hydrated ion pair can be observed in the 1H NMR spectrum of these same crystals with the same chemical shift of δ 10.8. Removal of the water proved difficult even under vacuum. The resonance at δ 10.8 could be reduced, but not completely removed, suggesting that the ion pair remains in contact in solution. An elemental analysis was successfully obtained following cation exchange with tetraethylammonium chloride in ethanol, giving a product which no longer contained water, Et  4  N-1. X-ray analysis of this material showed it to be water-free.

elements.content: Sodium could also be incorporated into the rhodium complex by exchanging the lithium cation. RhCl3·nH2O was mixed with Li-bdmpza and sodium chloride in methanol. Following heating of the reaction mixture at 50 °C for 20 h, [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−Na+ (Na-1) was obtained in 51% yield (eq ).

elements.content: The iridium analogue of the rhodium chloride complexes was also prepared by stirring Li-bdmpza and IrCl3·nH2O in methanol at room temperature to form [Ir­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−Li+ (Li-2). 1H NMR spectroscopy and ESI-MS suggested that the new complex was analogous to Li-1; however, this complex was difficult to further characterize due to its insolubility in common organic solvents. These issues were resolved by the addition of sodium chloride and heating the reaction mixture for 4 h (required) to produce the sodium adduct [Ir­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−Na+ (Na-2). Noticeable changes in the 1H NMR spectrum, a proper elemental analysis, and a single-crystal X-ray structure (Figure ) confirmed the cation exchange. No water was seen in the Na+ salt, but there were interactions of the sodium with two acetates and four chloride ligands in two neighboring molecules of Na-2 (CN = 6).

elements.content: A neutral rhodium complex was also synthesized to increase solubility in less polar solvents by the addition of pyridine to RhCl3·nH2O and Li-bdmpza in ethanol (Scheme ). Upon heating at temperatures below 50 °C, the C s -symmetrical complex [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl2(py)] (3a) was isolated. A single-crystal X-ray structure (Figure ) showed pyridine trans to the acetate. The thermodynamic asymmetric product with pyridine trans to pyrazole (3b) can be isolated by heating the reaction mixture to reflux for 24 h. All three of these new bdmpza complexes were tested for H/D exchange catalysis, as described below.

elements.content: Electrophilic H/D exchange with benzene was examined by using silver ion to remove chloride ion in the presence of a deuterium source. Three deuterated solvents were tested for H/D exchange with benzene, and the progress was analyzed using GCMS and NMR spectroscopy. CD3CO2D and CD3OD as deuterium sources showed no evidence for H/D exchange with C6H6 using 4% Na-1 and 3 equiv of silver trifluoroacetate (AgO2CCF3) at 100 °C (Table , entries 1 and 2). In contrast, 50 turnovers were observed when trifluoroacetic acid-d (TFA-d ) was used as the deuterium source under the same conditions (Table , entry 3). A negligible increase in H/D exchange was observed when the reaction temperature was increased from 100 to 110 °C (entry 4), but a substantial decrease to 35 turnovers was observed when the reaction temperature was increased further to 125 °C (entry 5), suggesting thermal decomposition of the catalyst.
elements.clean_text:
Benzene H/D Exchange

Electrophilic H/D exchange with benzene was examined by using silver ion to remove chloride ion in the presence of a deuterium source. Three deuterated solvents were tested for H/D exchange with benzene, and the progress was analyzed using GCMS and NMR spectroscopy. CD3CO2D and CD3OD as deuterium sources showed no evidence for H/D exchange with C6H6 using 4% Na-1 and 3 equiv of silver trifluoroacetate (AgO2CCF3) at 100 °C (Table , entries 1 and 2). In contrast, 50 turnovers were observed when trifluoroacetic acid-d  (TFA-d ) was used as the deuterium source under the same conditions (Table , entry 3). A negligible increase in H/D exchange was observed when the reaction temperature was increased from 100 to 110 °C (entry 4), but a substantial decrease to 35 turnovers was observed when the reaction temperature was increased further to 125 °C (entry 5), suggesting thermal decomposition of the catalyst.

Reaction conditions: 0.01 mmol of Na-1; 0.5 mL of DX; 23 μL of C6H6 (0.26 mmol); 3 equiv of Ag salt unless otherwise indicated; 24 h.

The deposition of white silver chloride is observed only after heating the solution, indicating that halide abstraction is difficult. Gravimetric isolation of the precipitate showed 2.3 equiv of silver chloride, implying two or possibly three chlorides had been removed. The use of different silver salts as a chloride abstractor and anion was also examined. Silver tetrafluoroborate showed no ability to produce an active catalyst (entry 8), yet when 3 equiv of silver triflate (AgOTf) was added to Na-1 an effective H/D exchange catalyst for benzene was formed (Table , entry 9). The addition of 1 equiv of AgOTf resulted in only 4 turnovers (entry 10); addition of an additional 1 equiv drastically increased the TON to 100 (entry 11). Remarkably, the addition of 3 equiv of AgOTf yielded 119 turnovers after 24 h, the statistical maximum for this catalytic reaction based on the equivalents of hydrogen and deuterium present. The 3:1 stoichiometry suggests a species such as [Rh­(bdmpza)­(solv)3]2+ or [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl­(solv)2]+ is the active species. The enhanced ability of AgOTf to produce an active catalyst over the other Ag+ salts can be attributed to its superior chloride abstraction capability.

elements.content: The conditions used in entry 9 of Table were employed to investigate H/D exchange of substituted arenes (Figure ). Integration of the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture (relative to an internal standard in a sealed capillary) was used to determine the extent and location of exchange. Na-1 was minimally effective at H/D exchange in monohaloarenes. Bromobenzene afforded the greatest deuterium incorporation, with only 23% exchange into the meta/para positions. No exchange was observed with 1,2-dichlorobenzene. Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized arenes showed modest H/D exchange into the C–H bonds of the arene (Figure ). Aniline exhibited 49% deuterium incorporation into the aryl ring, while N,N-dimethylaniline showed only 25% deuterium exchange into the arene. Methoxy and hydroxy derivatives experienced higher levels of deuteration, with 64% and 62% exchange into the meta and para positions, respectively. Exchange into the ortho positions of those substrates varied, with 77% and 55% exchange, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
H/D Exchange of Substituted Arenes

The conditions used in entry 9 of Table  were employed to investigate H/D exchange of substituted arenes (Figure ). Integration of the 1H NMR spectrum of the reaction mixture (relative to an internal standard in a sealed capillary) was used to determine the extent and location of exchange. Na-1 was minimally effective at H/D exchange in monohaloarenes. Bromobenzene afforded the greatest deuterium incorporation, with only 23% exchange into the meta/para positions. No exchange was observed with 1,2-dichlorobenzene. Nitrogen- and oxygen-functionalized arenes showed modest H/D exchange into the C-H bonds of the arene (Figure ). Aniline exhibited 49% deuterium incorporation into the aryl ring, while N,N-dimethylaniline showed only 25% deuterium exchange into the arene. Methoxy and hydroxy derivatives experienced higher levels of deuteration, with 64% and 62% exchange into the meta and para positions, respectively. Exchange into the ortho positions of those substrates varied, with 77% and 55% exchange, respectively.

elements.content: Alkylbenzenes exhibited high percentages of deuterium exchange into the arene rings, and some molecules even showed modest exchange into the β-alkyl C–H bonds of the substituent (Figure ). Neopentylbenzene showed 81% deuterium incorporation into the arene but no incorporation into the alkyl group. Notably, this substrate lacks a β-C–H bond. n-Propylbenzene and ethylbenzene showed nearly identical deuterium inclusion in the ortho, meta, and para positions, averaging 79%.

elements.content: Interestingly, only branched alkyl β-C–H bonds showed exchange, while n-alkyl substitutents curiously showed no exchange. Cumene, tert-butylbenzene, and sec-butylbenzene all showed deuterium incorporation in the arene ring and β-C–H bond of the R group. The β-C–H bonds in cumene showed 47% exchange, whereas tert-butylbenzene showed the highest β-H/D exchange at 62%. The two different environments of sec-butylbenzene showed 33% and 30% exchange, respectively, of the methyl and methylene protons. Neither ethylbenzene nor propylbenzene showed methyl H/D exchange, indicating that branching is important to the mechanism of the reaction.

The two different environments of sec-butylbenzene showed 33% and 30% exchange, respectively, of the methyl and methylene protons. Neither ethylbenzene nor propylbenzene showed methyl H/D exchange, indicating that branching is important to the mechanism of the reaction.

elements.content: The iridium analogue [Ir­(bdmpza)­Cl3]−Na+ (Na-2) and the pyridine derivative [Rh­(bdmpza)­Cl2(py)] (3b) were also examined under the same conditions and showed comparable affinity for H/D exchange of both benzene and substituted arenes. In substrates with no alkyl β-C–H bonds, such as toluene, Na-2 showed 88% ortho/meta and 87% para deuterium incorporation, while 3b produced 82% ortho/meta and 86% para. Similarly to Na-1, neither catalyst activated alkyl β-C–H bonds of ethylbenzene and n-propylbenzene. Na-2 had a lower affinity for alkyl β-H/D exchange relative to Na-1 with 17% and 13% deuterium incorporation of cumene and sec-butylbenzene, respectively, under identical conditions. 3b also showed a lower percentage of deuterium exchange with 25% and 22% incorporation, respectively, for cumene and sec-butylbenzene under identical conditions.

elements.content: Control reactions of cumene H/D exchange were also investigated. RhCl3·H2O in TFA-d did not activate the alkyl β-C–H bond, but 53% para deuterium exchange and only 16% ortho/meta deuterium exchange was observed (100 °C, 24 h). When 3 equiv of AgOTf were added to the reaction mixture, a small amount (12%) of deuterium incorporation was seen in the β-C–H bonds. The addition of 1 equiv of Li-bdmpza to a second sample along with 3 equiv of AgOTf inhibited this β-H/D exchange. These observations indicate that with silver and no ligand present, a Rh­(III) solvento complex is being formed that has some catalytic activity, but less than for the complexes studied here.

elements.content: In addition to 24 h H/D exchange experiments, a few exchange reactions were monitored as a function of time to see if there was any kinetic selectivity in the exchange. Initial results showed that cumene at 100 °C exhibited rapid H/D exchange into the para position using Na-1 (Figure ). Since H/D exchange is reversible, the percentage of deuterium in the arene ring decreases as equilibration with the methyl groups occurs, eventually leading to a statistical distribution. We investigated the reaction further by lowering the temperature to 60 °C, which confirmed that the para position rapidly undergoes H/D exchange (Figure a). After 1.5 h 8% exchange was observed in the para position, reaching a maximum of 83% after 11 h. The deuterium exchange rate for the ortho/meta positions was slower, having only 42% exchange after 11 h and still exchanging after 32 h. Interestingly, no methyl H/D exchange was observed at the lower temperature. From these data, the barrier to methyl H/D exchange can be approximated as ∼30 kcal mol–1, compared to ∼26 kcal mol–1 for aryl exchange.

elements.content: From the data in Figure , TOFs of 40, 20, and 1.6 h–1 can be calculated for para, meta + ortho, and methyl exchange by Na-1, respectively, in cumene at early reaction times (1–8 h). These H/D exchange reactions can be compared with other recent literature reports of H/D exchange by dividing reported turnover numbers (TONs) by reaction times to obtain turnover frequencies (TOFs). Sanford recently reported use of a series of platinum dipyridine/diimine complexes that exchange deuterium between TFA-d or CD3CO2D and benzene at 150 °C. TOFs of up to 720 h–1 were seen using acetic acid and AgBF4 as chloride abstractor. This group also found a dicationic bipyridyl platinum complex that displayed a TOF of 360 h–1 for benzene/CD3COOD exchange at 150 °C. There is evidence for minor amounts (2–8%) of exchange into β-alkyl positions with this catalyst. Goldberg has reported a PNP-pincer rhodium phenoxide complex that catalyzes exchange of deuterium between D2O and benzene at 100 °C with a TOF of 0.1 h–1, apparently by a mechanism involving initial loss of phenoxide. Two other systems that employ alkoxide groups for H/D exchange are those reported by Gunnoe and Periana. Gunnoe found that TpRu­(PMe3)2(OH) catalyzes exchange between benzene and water at 100 °C with a TOF of 0.058 h–1. Periana found that Ir­(acac)2(OPh)­(py) catalyzes exchange between benzene and water at 160 °C with a TOF of 9.7 h–1. Bergman reported that [Cp*IrCl2]2 catalyzes H/D exchange between aromatic (and pendant aliphatic C–H bonds) and D2O at 135 °C with a TOF of 0.55 h–1. Ison has reported increased activities of several related catalysts of the type Cp*Ir­(NHC)­X2 (X2 = Cl2, (NCMe)2, (OH2)2, SO4, (NO3)2, (TFA)2, Cl/OTf). These complexes catalyze benzene/CD3OD/D2O exchange with TOFs of 3.2–9.3 h–1. Finally, Bergman has reported perhaps the most active H/D exchange catalyst known, [Cp*Ir­(CH2Cl2)­H]+[MeB­(C6F5)3]−. This compound catalyzes H/D exchange between C6D6 and toluene at −20 °C with a TOF of 8.1 h–1. The compound also catalyzes H/D exchange into alkanes (including methane) more slowly, but also at −20 °C.

elements.content: H/D exchange into the aromatic C–H bonds is proposed to occur by the concerted metalation–deprotonation mechanism (also referred to as ambiphilic metal ligand deprotonation), for which there is strong support in the prior work of Fagnou and Davies. Further discussion of this pathway will be given in the section describing DFT treatment of this system.
elements.clean_text:
Proposed Mechanism

H/D exchange into the aromatic C-H bonds is proposed to occur by the concerted metalation-deprotonation mechanism (also referred to as ambiphilic metal ligand deprotonation), for which there is strong support in the prior work of Fagnou and Davies. Further discussion of this pathway will be given in the section describing DFT treatment of this system.

elements.content: The exclusive exchange into the β-C–H bonds of branched alkylbenzenes presents a more puzzling challenge. The observation of β-exchange in tert-butylbenzene and the lack of α-exchange in isopropylbenzene rules out a pathway involving α-activation followed by reversible β-elimination. Three possible mechanisms are shown in Scheme that could account for this H/D exchange. Pathway A would accommodate H/D exchange by the formation of three facial open sites created by the removal of the three chloride ligands. Isolation of 2.3 mol of silver chloride per rhodium by gravometric study indicated that it was possible for the metal center to lose three chlorides, creating three open sites for activation. While 3b has only two chlorides, dissociation of pyridine could occur and might explain its slower rate of reaction. In this pathway, concerted metalation–deprotonation (CMD) activation of the arene brings the β-C–H bonds close enough to the metal for oxidative addition. Pathway B also involves initial CMD activation of the arene C–H bond. Dissociation of the pendant acetate group could form a third open coordination site. The acetate could facilitate C–H activation by formation of carboxylic acid by the well-established metalation–deprotonation pathway, creating a five-membered metalocycle. Attempts to isolate the active catalyst under reaction conditions have been unsuccessful, as these species were not stable.

elements.content: Studies of the reactivity of [Rh­(bdmpz)­Cl3(py)] (4; eq ), an analogue without the carboxylate group, were carried out to provide insight into the role of the acetate group. Complex 4 was synthesized under conditions similar to the synthesis of 3; bis­(3,5-dimethylpyrazole)­methane, rhodium trichloride hydrate, and pyridine were heated to reflux in ethanol overnight. The solid that formed was extracted with methylene chloride, allowing for the isolation of 4, which was characterized by 1H NMR spectroscopy and elemental analysis. Use of 4 as a precatalyst under the same conditions used for cumene H/D exchange afforded a more active catalyst with 63% deuterium inclusion into the β-C–H bond. This observation indicated that the tethered acetate does not participate in the reaction (see the discussion of DFT results for further analysis).

elements.content: Use of a substrate which contains substituents ortho to the alkyl group with β-C–H bonds could provide insight into the importance of arene activation by the metal center. 1,3,5-Trimethyl-2-isopropylbenzene was synthesized using Friedel–Crafts alkylation of mesitylene with tin tetrachloride. The monosubstituted species was the major product, which was then examined for H/D exchange using the catalyst Na-1/AgOTf. In the 2H NMR spectrum, arene and β-C–H bond H/D exchange were observed, with 34% deuterium inclusion into the β-C–H bonds of the substituent. These studies concluded that pathway A with exchange via C–H bond activation of the arene and pathway B with exchange mediated by bdmpza do not occur.

The monosubstituted species was the major product, which was then examined for H/D exchange using the catalyst Na-1/AgOTf. In the 2H NMR spectrum, arene and β-C-H bond H/D exchange were observed, with 34% deuterium inclusion into the β-C-H bonds of the substituent. These studies concluded that pathway A with exchange via C-H bond activation of the arene and pathway B with exchange mediated by bdmpza do not occur.

elements.content: Pathway C involves coordination of the arene through a π-bond and TFA η1 through the carbonyl. This species could exchange aromatic C–H bonds via the typical CMD pathway involving coordinated trifluoroacetate. In the case of a branched alkylbenzene a spatial arrangement in which the β-C–H bond could readily undergo C–H activation would be created. No hydride or deuteride resonance was observed in the 1H NMR or 2H NMR spectra during the reaction, which could be attributed to collection of NMR data at room temperature vs the elevated temperatures needed for β-C–H bond exchange. The lack of a hydride/deuteride resonance suggests coordination of trifluoroacetate to promote a base-assisted mechanism rather than an oxidative addition pathway involving Rh­(V), although if the oxidative addition were rate determining, one would not observe a hydride resonance. Use of catalyst 4 could show increased rates if the pyridine is labile, since the sterics around the metal center would be decreased, allowing more room for coordination of the arene and trifluoroacetate. Finally, if no ortho arene activation was required, H/D exchange would be expected to occur in substrates with coordinatively saturated ortho positions.

This species could exchange aromatic C-H bonds via the typical CMD pathway involving coordinated trifluoroacetate. In the case of a branched alkylbenzene a spatial arrangement in which the β-C-H bond could readily undergo C-H activation would be created. No hydride or deuteride resonance was observed in the 1H NMR or 2H NMR spectra during the reaction, which could be attributed to collection of NMR data at room temperature vs the elevated temperatures needed for β-C-H bond exchange. The lack of a hydride/deuteride resonance suggests coordination of trifluoroacetate to promote a base-assisted mechanism rather than an oxidative addition pathway involving Rh(V), although if the oxidative addition were rate determining, one would not observe a hydride resonance. Use of catalyst 4 could show increased rates if the pyridine is labile, since the sterics around the metal center would be decreased, allowing more room for coordination of the arene and trifluoroacetate. Finally, if no ortho arene activation was required, H/D exchange would be expected to occur in substrates with coordinatively saturated ortho positions.

elements.content: Scheme shows a possible mechanism for β-alkyl exchange in which Na-1 first undergoes loss of three chloride ligands to form the η2-trifluoroacetate complex 5 with cumene. Coordination of the arene would facilitate alkyl C–H activation. Dissociation of an acetate arm to form an η1-acetate would lead to TS-6. The short-lived intermediate 7 would be formed as the TFA exchanges hydrogen for deuterium. A similar transition state for bond formation, TS-6- d , could provide for deuterium incorporation into the substrate. Davies and co-workers have recently reported computational calculations of [Ir­(κ2-OAc)­(PMe3)­Cp]+ benzene C–H activation. They propose that the initial step of η2 to η1 displacement of acetate leads to an energy barrier of 28.4 kcal mol–1 for benzene C–H activation and that it is the noncoordinated oxygen that accepts a proton from the C–H bond of the π-coordinated arene. Such higher energy intermediates can explain why no stoichiometric benzene activation occurs and also explains the difficulty of isolating possible reaction intermediates. A Thorpe–Ingold effect could explain why H/D exchange was observed only in branched β-alkyl arenes, or the more favorable statistics with having two or three alkyl groups near the metal could account for the observed selectivity. Furthermore, the lack of participation of the bdmpza acetate in the reaction is likely due to the inability to achieve the proper CMD transition state due to the chelate geometry, which places the carbonyl oxygen away from the arene coordination site.

The short-lived intermediate 7 would be formed as the TFA exchanges hydrogen for deuterium. Davies and co-workers have recently reported computational calculations of [Ir(κ2-OAc)(PMe3)Cp]+ benzene C-H activation. Such higher energy intermediates can explain why no stoichiometric benzene activation occurs and also explains the difficulty of isolating possible reaction intermediates. elements.clean_text: 4  Proposed Mechanism of H/D Exchange by Na-1

elements.content: We have employed DFT methods (using PCM correction in acetic acid solvent) to examine the nature of the intermediates and transition states suggested in Scheme , which provides supporting evidence for the cumene complexes 5, TS-6, and 7 as σ-C,H adducts rather than π-C,C adducts. Indeed, if one begins with an η2-C,C cumene structure in place of 5, optimization leads to the η2-C,H σ structure (Figure a). Starting with optimization of intermediate 5 (σ-C,H bound) as the zero of energy, a stable product is found at +15.6 kcal/mol for the cyclometalated species 7. As mentioned above, the structure of this intermediate, however, does not display an η2-C,C bound arene but rather maintains an η2-C,H σ interaction with the ortho arene C–H bond. It is worth noting that a similar sp3 C–H activation has been seen by Fagnou and by Clot and Baudoin in Pd-C6H4-t-Bu complexes, and DFT calculations show pathways similar to those presented here, although the aryl group was σ-bound directly to the metal. Next, a transition state was located for TS-6 (Figure b), which connects via intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations to both 5 and 7. Here again, the arene is observed to bind in an η2-C,H rather than η2-C,C fashion. The energy of the transition state is 32.3 kcal/mol above 5, close to the experimental barrier of ∼30 kcal/mol. The overall pathway and energy for β-exchange is shown in Figure .
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations of the Mechanism

We have employed DFT methods (using PCM correction in acetic acid solvent) to examine the nature of the intermediates and transition states suggested in Scheme , which provides supporting evidence for the cumene complexes 5, TS-6, and 7 as σ-C,H adducts rather than π-C,C adducts. Indeed, if one begins with an η2-C,C cumene structure in place of 5, optimization leads to the η2-C,H σ structure (Figure a). Starting with optimization of intermediate 5 (σ-C,H bound) as the zero of energy, a stable product is found at +15.6 kcal/mol for the cyclometalated species 7. As mentioned above, the structure of this intermediate, however, does not display an η2-C,C bound arene but rather maintains an η2-C,H σ interaction with the ortho arene C-H bond. It is worth noting that a similar sp3 C-H activation has been seen by Fagnou and by Clot and Baudoin in Pd-C6H4-t-Bu complexes, and DFT calculations show pathways similar to those presented here, although the aryl group was σ-bound directly to the metal. Next, a transition state was located for TS-6 (Figure b), which connects via intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations to both 5 and 7. Here again, the arene is observed to bind in an η2-C,H rather than η2-C,C fashion. The energy of the transition state is 32.3 kcal/mol above 5, close to the experimental barrier of ~30 kcal/mol. The overall pathway and energy for β-exchange is shown in Figure .

elements.content: We have also located the transition state for arene C–H activation of cumene (TS-8, Figure c), leading to the aryl derivative 9 (eq ). Here, the η2-C,H intermediate 5 proceeds to transfer a hydrogen to the trifluoroacetate carbonyl, as is typically proposed for the concerted metalation–deprotonation pathway and is very similar to the calculated ambiphilic metal ligand activation (AMLA) pathway reported by Davies and MacGregor.

elements.content: From these transition states, one can also see why the pendant acetate group of the bdmpza ligand is not effective for participation in CMD. Even though the carboxylate is η1, the carbonyl oxygen is pointed away from the metal center where it cannot assist in the deprotonation of the C–H bond.

elements.content: Finally, we have also located the transition state for activation of the α-C–H bond (TS-10) to produce benzyl product 11 and determined the barrier to activation (eq ). TS-10 is calculated to lie 44.1 kcal/mol above 5, which is too high to permit activation at this location. Consequently, the DFT calculations mirror the experimental observations with regard to ease of H/D exchange: aromatic sp2 > β-sp3 ≫ α-sp3.

Consequently, the DFT calculations mirror the experimental observations with regard to ease of H/D exchange: aromatic sp2 > β-sp3 ≫ α-sp3. 4

elements.content: We have also examined the binding abilities of acetate vs trifluoroacetate in 5. Experimentally, only TFA-d was an effective deuterium source for H/D exchange. CD3CO2D showed no exchange. We find that calculation of the exchange between trifluoroacetate and acetic acid in 5 indicates that the acetate adduct is preferred by 2.5 kcal/mol (eq ), although this calculation neglects any differential solvation of the acetic acid vs trifluoroacetic acid. Calculation of the barrier to arene C–H bond activation from the acetate complex 5′ was determined by optimizing the transition state TS-8′, which is similar to TS-8 but with acetate replacing trifluoroacetate. The barrier for H/D exchange of ΔG ⧧ = 25.6 kcal/mol indicates that this might be possible, in contrast to what is observed experimentally, although the barrier is not as low as when trifluoroacetate is present. Davies and Macgregor have examined the effects of different basic ligands (O2CMe, O2CCF3, SO3CF3, O2COH, O2CPh, O2CCCl3) on the barrier to C–H activation using DFT and found that trifluoroacetate had the lowest barrier (∼O2CCCl3), with the barrier for acetate about 4 kcal mol–1 higher. Experimentally, however, acetate catalyzed exchange much faster than triflate, leading them to conclude that C–H activation was not rate determining. The same may be true in the present case, where 5 (or 5′) must form by displacement of a bound solvent molecule. If acetic acid were to bind more strongly, this could account for the observed lack of reactivity in CD3CO2D.

elements.content: In all of these calculations a polarized continuum model (PCM) solvation correction is applied to these species using acetic acid as the solvent, as Gaussian does not offer TFA as a solvent, which may also introduce some inaccuracy.

elements.content: Three new rhodium and iridium complexes were synthesized and characterized with the fac-chelating ligand bdmpza. Catalytic benzene H/D exchange was observed when trifluoroacetic acid-d was used as the deuterium source. This reaction was optimized, with the best conditions being the addition of 3 equiv of silver triflate to form the active catalyst in situ. These conditions were then employed to investigate H/D exchange of substituted arenes. Aromatic exchange was the most facile. Notably, branched alkyl substituents on arenes showed H/D exchange exclusively into the sp3 β-C–H bonds but not into the α-C–H bonds. DFT calculations suggested η1-C–H arene coordination followed by base-assisted C–H activation of the β-C–H bond leading to H/D exchange.

Conclusion

Three new rhodium and iridium complexes were synthesized and characterized with the fac-chelating ligand bdmpza. Catalytic benzene H/D exchange was observed when trifluoroacetic acid-d  was used as the deuterium source. This reaction was optimized, with the best conditions being the addition of 3 equiv of silver triflate to form the active catalyst in situ. These conditions were then employed to investigate H/D exchange of substituted arenes. Aromatic exchange was the most facile. Notably, branched alkyl substituents on arenes showed H/D exchange exclusively into the sp3 β-C-H bonds but not into the α-C-H bonds. DFT calculations suggested η1-C-H arene coordination followed by base-assisted C-H activation of the β-C-H bond leading to H/D exchange.

elements.content: In a typical reaction, a 4 mL ampule was charged with catalyst (5.0 mg, 0.01 mmol), 25 equiv of benzene (23 μL, 0.25 mmol), and deuterated solvent (0.5 mL, 6.5 mmol). The ampule was then degassed and placed in a heated block at 100–125 °C. After 24 h, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. Once it was cooled, the mixture was passed through a small Celite plug and diluted with 1 mL of methylene chloride or ethyl acetate. The solution was then analyzed by GC-MS. Deuterium exchange was determined by input of data using the method published by Periana.

General Procedure for Catalytic H/D Exchange Experiments with Benzene

In a typical reaction, a 4 mL ampule was charged with catalyst (5.0 mg, 0.01 mmol), 25 equiv of benzene (23 μL, 0.25 mmol), and deuterated solvent (0.5 mL, 6.5 mmol). The ampule was then degassed and placed in a heated block at 100-125 °C. After 24 h, the reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature. Once it was cooled, the mixture was passed through a small Celite plug and diluted with 1 mL of methylene chloride or ethyl acetate. The solution was then analyzed by GC-MS. Deuterium exchange was determined by input of data using the method published by Periana.

elements.content: In a typical reaction, a J. Young NMR tube was charged with catalyst (5.0 mg, 0.01 mmol), 25 equiv of cumene (34 μL, 0.25 mmol), deuterated solvent (0.5 mL, 6.5 mmol), and a sealed capillary tube containing tetramethylsilane and toluene-d 8. The tube was degassed, and an initial 1H NMR spectrum was obtained. The tube was placed in a 100 °C oil bath for 24 h. The reaction mixture was cooled to room temperature, and both 1H NMR and 2H NMR spectra were obtained. The percent deuterium exchange was calculated by monitoring changes in the integration of the substrate resonances relative to the internal standard.

The tube was degassed, and an initial 1H NMR spectrum was obtained. The tube was placed in a 100 °C oil bath for 24 h. The percent deuterium exchange was calculated by monitoring changes in the integration of the substrate resonances relative to the internal standard.

elements.content: All calculations were performed using the Gaussian09 package. The B3LYP functional was used in both geometry optimization and single-point energy calculations. The Rh atom was represented with the effective core pseudopotentials of the Stuttgart group and the associated basis sets improved with a set of f-polarization functions for Rh (α = 1.350). The remaining atoms (C, H, O, and F) were represented with 6-31G** basis sets. Each transition state has only one imaginary frequency, and the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) routes were calculated in both directions for every transition state toward the corresponding minima. The self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) calculations using the PCM-UA0 solvation model were carried out for the gas-phase optimized structures. The energies discussed in the potential energy surface plot are free energies from PCM correction in acetic acid, which have been calculated at 298.15 K and 1 atm.
elements.clean_text:
General Procedure for DFT Calculations

All calculations were performed using the Gaussian09 package. The B3LYP functional was used in both geometry optimization and single-point energy calculations. The Rh atom was represented with the effective core pseudopotentials of the Stuttgart group and the associated basis sets improved with a set of f-polarization functions for Rh (α = 1.350). The remaining atoms (C, H, O, and F) were represented with 6-31G** basis sets. Each transition state has only one imaginary frequency, and the intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) routes were calculated in both directions for every transition state toward the corresponding minima. The self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) calculations using the PCM-UA0 solvation model were carried out for the gas-phase optimized structures. The energies discussed in the potential energy surface plot are free energies from PCM correction in acetic acid, which have been calculated at 298.15 K and 1 atm.

The authors declare no competing financial interest.

References

For structural details of Et 4 N-1, see the .

We employed the method described by Periana to determine the turnover number (TON) from the GCMS data.

A control experiment employing only AgTFA in TFA solvent under the same conditions showed no H/D exchange at 100 °C.

At 12 mol % catalyst loading of silver triflate 4 turnovers were observed after 24 h.

For CH3 exchange at 100 °C, τ1/2 ≈ 10 h, which implies k ≈ 2 × 10–5 s–1 and ΔG ⧧ ≈ 30 kcal mol–1. For aryl exchange at 60 °C, τ1/2 ≈ 4 h, which implies k ≈ 5 × 10–5 s–1 and ΔG ⧧ ≈ 26 kcal mol–1.

[Rh(bdmpza)Cl3]-Li+ (Li-1)

A round-bottom flask was charged with Li-bdmpza (487.1 mg, 1.9 mmol), RhCl3⋅H2O (503.0 mg, 1.9 mmol), and 30 mL of ethanol. After gentle heating for 8 h the solvent was removed under vacuum. The solid was washed with methylene chloride (3 × 5 mL) by filtration. The solid was then dissolved in THF, and insoluble impurities were removed. THF solvent was evaporated under vacuum, yielding 0.428 g (48%) of product. 1H NMR (THF-d 8): δ 2.61 (s, 6H, CH3), 2.70 (s, 6H, CH3), 6.05 (s, 2H, CH), 7.13 (s, 1H, HCCO2), 10.86 (br, ~1H, H2O).

[Rh(bdmpza)Cl3]-N(Et)4 + (Et  4  N-1)

[Rh(bdmpza)Cl3]-Li+ (174.1 mg, 0.3 mmol) was dissolved in 10 mL of ethanol in a round-bottom flask. Tetraethylammonium chloride (79.1 mg, 0.4 mmol) was first dissolved in 2 mL of ethanol and added dropwise. After 15 min of stirring, anion exchange occurred with precipitation, and a new solid was isolated by filtration. Yield: 0.075 g (34%). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 400 MHz): δ 1.35 (Et4N+), 2.44 (s, 6H, CH3), 2.84 (s, 6H, CH3), 3.44 (Et4N+), 6.01 (s, 2H, CH), 6.37 (s, 1H, HCCO2). Anal. A round-bottom flask was charged with Li-bdmpza (343.0 mg, 1.3 mmol), RhCl3⋅H2O (357.4 mg, 1.3 mmol), sodium chloride (89.0 mg, 1.5 mmol), and 30 mL of methanol.
